Our wise decision-makers are our best asset, yet many people are willing to sacrifice them as scapegoats when the real culprit is randomness. If you have reason to believe that someone‚Äôs decision process is top notch, don‚Äôt hold a bad outcome against them. 17 /üßµ
Outcome bias exerts a terrible price on society. 16 /üßµ

Either way, you‚Äôve just voted to shrink society‚Äôs pool of competent decision-makers, punishing Heather for randomness (outcome) when you should have celebrated her wise action in light of what she knew at the time (decision). 15 /üßµ

Well, here are the two most likely reasons someone has never caused a bad outcome:

üçºInexperience - They‚Äôre less experienced than Heather, so they have a spotless track record.
üÉèLuck - They‚Äôve been lucky. (Look up survivorship bias when you get a moment.) 14 /üßµ

If you‚Äôre outcome-biased, you‚Äôll blame her for the outcome ‚Äî forgetting that she made the decision wisely ‚Äî and you‚Äôll clamor for her to be replaced with another decision-maker who doesn‚Äôt have bad outcomes to their name. 13 /üßµ
Like Heather, you would have chosen the coin, but you‚Äôre not thinking about that. You‚Äôre too busy focusing on the bad outcome she got: tails+6 = missed opportunity for $100. 12 /üßµ

Outcome bias threatens society‚Äôs ability to promote and retain competent leaders. 

Suppose the decision between betting on the coin and the die wasn‚Äôt yours to make. Instead, you watched Heather make it. 11 /üßµ

Otherwise, you might choose a fair die instead of a fair coin next time. That would be a stupid choice if you like money. No matter how you slice it, 50% to win is a better gamble than 17% for the same prize. 10 /üßµ
If we look at outcomes, you got $0 when you could have had $100. Can we fix that? Nope, that decision is over. What should you learn from it? Nothing, I hope. 9 /üßµ
Always evaluate decision quality based only on what was known at the time the decision was made. 8 /üßµ

No. No, you shouldn‚Äôt have. Definitely not. That‚Äôs outcome bias and it‚Äôs a habit you should kick as soon as you can ‚Äî especially if you have any hopes of being a good leader or decision-maker. 7 /üßµ

6 /üßµ

We all need some bad habits.

Do your best to leave them with something that will be useful to them later, whether it's when they're cooking the dish themselves one day (here's how not to set the house on fire!) or it's a lesson, a laugh, or a good story. Give them a gift for the gift of their attention. üéÅ

Finally, put oomph into your presentation. Practice making cookbooks interesting and you can make your research niche interesting too. Use flair. Tell stories. Make it relatable. And give them something they can tell their non-chef friends when they go home. üßµ
Above all, respect your audience's attention. Listening to you is hard work. Make it easy on them! Make it worthwhile. Don't drone on as if they owe you their ears. üßµ

You should also think about what you're trying to motivate. Do you want them to cook it? Tell them why they'll benefit by cooking it. Do you want them to fund you to cook it? Tell them why they'll benefit by funding it. üßµ
But even a non-baker might look up from their phone if you put it in context, "This is the only croissant recipe that works at 500 degrees." or "Most ovens don't go that high." etc. üßµ

Then think about which details are interesting at which level of expertise. If you're talking to me about baking, you will bore me to tears by telling me the oven temperature. But maybe professional pasty chefs would say, "Whoa, you preset the oven to 500 degrees??? Amazing!" üßµ

What's the first order of business? Understanding that if they're not cooking it *right now* then certain details aren't interesting/memorable. Even if they're math-savvy enough to understand those details.

Make sure you tell them *where* to find the recipe when they need it. üßµ

Never assume anyone cares as much as you do. They don't. You likely care more than anyone in the room and you have to *make* them care. It's your job to figure out how. Practice with the cookbook! üßµ

Try pick a recipe that isn't near to your heart, this will help you empathize with audience members who aren't already excited about your niche thing. Picking a dull recipe will be great practice for seeing their perspective. üßµ

You and other non-experts can understand what you're reading if you put a bit of effort in, and yet it would make you want to claw your eyes out if someone wrote out the recipe on a board while mumbling. Or mumbling over a LaTeX slide of it. (Welcome to math presentations.) üßµ

Technical disciplines have a lot in common with cooking. Think about it. Lots to nerd out about if you care to, lots of nitty gritty details, requires some step by step thinking...

So the use of cookbooks for practice isn't all the way outlandish, but what's even better is üßµ

My top tip for learning to be a great technical presenter, even if your content is very equations-heavy:

Open a cookbook at random and meditate on how you would present it in a way that doesn't put your audience to sleep.

Yeah, I'm not joking.

The upshot? You'll have to study yourself. Unless you test your own responses to various approaches for motivating yourself, you won't know how to construct a program that works best for you. Which means you have to fail. If you're not failing, it means you're not testing. 20/üßµ

But different people are different, so what works for you might not be what works for anyone else. To hack your motivation, you'll need need to know how you respond to one kind of performance goal vs another. You'll need know which circumstances affect ‚¨ÜÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è your motivation. 18/üßµ

Serving suggestion: Start by trying out a 6h window and adjust to your taste.

Similarly, don't forget to build in a plan to adjust your goal if you find out it wasn't well-designed. Maybe you resolved to run an extra 5 miles each week, but you get so tired you can't focus at work. Without a plan for adapting 5 to 2 miles, you might abandon running. 15/üßµ

Don't let a teensy tiny mistake ruin your chance at doing better this year than last year. At the end of the day, any improvement is better than none at all. That's the point of the resolution. Doing better, getting closer to the version of you that you want to be. 14/üßµ

Example: if you resolve to run 5 more miles every week, make sure you have a plan for how you'll get back on track if you slip up. What if you miss a week because you got sick? What's the plan? Do you give up? Is the whole flimsy thing ruined? I hope not. 13/üßµ
